description.narrative: Increased capacities of communities to protect development gains and achieve improved well-being outcomes in the face of shocks and stresses enabling them to contribute to the economic growth of Zimbabwe

participating-org.narrative: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS

activity-description.narrative: Output 1. Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented; Output 2. Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level

Output 1. Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented; Output 2. Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Output 1. Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented; Output 2. Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

provider-org.narrative: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS
FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS

description.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased. # of national and sub-national assessments that inform development planning and programming, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men # of knowledge products at national and subnational levels that inform resilience planning and programming # of community projects that utilize evidence for improved resilience.
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities improved via ZRBF investments # of women and men supported by ZRBF funded programmes to cope with the effects of climate change disaggregated by type of investment # of at risk communities (wards) with a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan Percentage of farmers who used financial services (savings, agricultural credit, and/or agricultural insurance) in the past 12 months # of communities with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively Number of women and men receiving trainings in the ZRBF programme (disaggregated by training type) Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation) Percentage of farmers who practiced the value chain activities promoted by the project in the past 12 months (f/m disaggregation) Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation -head of household) supported by ZRBF # of functional small scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type)
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
- Crisis modifiers designed and built int

comment.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: Effective evidence based institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place at national and sub-national levels for increased resilience
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved via ZRBF investments.
- Unknown (baseline will be done as part of the project)
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.

Output 1: Effective evidence based institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place at national and sub-national levels for increased resilience. 1.1 Number of national and sub-national risk assessments that inform development planning and programming, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men (5) 1.2 Number of multi-hazard mappings at subnational levels that inform resilience planning and programming (2 multi-hazard mappings) 1.3 Robust program monitoring, evaluation & learning strategic framework is established and operationalized to monitor and evaluate ZRBF program implementation progress and outcomes (ZRBF monitoring, evaluation & learning strategic framework harmonization with the implementing partners & baseline survey finalized)
Output 2:The absorptive, adaptive and trans-formative capacities in vulnerable communities improved.
2.1 Number of women and men supported by ZRBF funded programmes to cope with the effects of climate change disaggregated by type of investment (364,500 people)
2.2 Number of at risk communities (wards) with a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan (65) 2.3 Number of communities with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively (61) 2.4 Number of women and men receiving trainings in the ZRBF programme (disaggregated by training type) (69,000) 2.4 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF (9,700) 2.5 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type)(400)
Output 3; Establish a crisis modifier mechanism that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas. 3.1 Crisis modifiers designed and built into ZRBFs multi-year development programs (Crisis modifier mechanism (CMM) standard operating procedure (SOP) and High Frequency Monitoring System (HFMS) updated and socialized) 3.2 Number of women & men assisted through the activation of ZRBF Crisis Modifier mechanism (22,500 people)

Output 1: Effective evidence based institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place at national and sub-national levels for increased resilience. 1.1 Number of national and sub-national risk assessments that inform development planning and programming, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men (Sub-national risk assessment (5); Resilience/ community adaption action plans for 5 districts have been finalized. Informed by the hazards mapping, institutional mapping, contextual analysis and scenario planning processes. Sizimele consortium operational districts (Insiza, Lupane, & Matobo) and ECRIMS consortium operational districts (Mberengwa & Zvishavane).
National risk assessments (a total of 2) that inform development planning and programming taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men. ZimVAC; and crop and livestock assessments)- this informed the ZRBF programming, CM & FAW response. )
1.2 Number of multi-hazard mappings at subnational levels that inform resilience planning and programming A total of 2 multi hazard maps produced to inform resilience planning and programming in the two second phase districts. These include district level and ward level (Matobo -Sizimele & Beitbridge -PROGRESS) 1.3 Robust program monitoring, evaluation & learning strategic framework is established and operationalized to monitor and evaluate ZRBF program implementation progress and outcomes  ZRBF Monitoring, evaluation & Learning strategic framework harmonization and MEL reflections with all consortia partners have been conducted twice during the reporting period.  A total of six internal performance monitoring field mission has been conducted as part of HACT to all the consortia partners, except ECRAS. Furthermore, a joint steering committee mission has been conducted to districts under ZRBF programming from the ECRAS consortium.  EU Results Oriented Monitoring mission was successfully completed in January and recommendations harmonized with recommendations from the 2017 DFID AR.  Quarterly consortia, development partners and steering committee performance review meetings have been successfully concluded.  Quarterly performance reporting produced and approved by the SC.  ZRBF PMU conducted a thorough midterm review and the results are used to inform the cost extension decision of the 1st round (2016) consortia projects to 2021 to allow additional time to consolidate results and promote resilience thinking in the districts.  The delayed Baseline survey report has been successfully completed and shared for review during the reporting period.
Output 2:The absorptive, adaptive and trans-formative capacities in vulnerable communities improved.
2.1 Number of women and men supported by ZRBF funded programmes to cope with the effects of climate change disaggregated by type of investment 524,682 people (178,392 males and 346,290 females, i.e. 66% were female)
Types of support ranges from crop and livestock activities, productive infrastructure development, access to water and sanitation, internal savings and lending (ISAL) groups, safety nets, and disaster risk management (DRM) activities.
ECRAS and ECRIMS projects have 13% and 25% youth representation respectively, while other consortia are still working on providing and cleaning age data for their project participants. Disability information is not available to report currently, however the projects have started working on ways to collect data for future reporting following discussions on leave no one behind.
Disaggregated results by investment type: Livestock Production-26,042 Community Financial Services-28,247 Disaster Risk Reduction-177,579 Demonstration Centres-4,090 Non-Timber Forest Products-19,980 Horticulture-3,942 Irrigated Crops-9328 Field Crops-68,949 Mechanisation- 684 Market Linkages & Value Chains-31,900 ICT & Communication-110,777 Infrastructure-112,262 Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH)-61,529 Aquaculture-522 Trainings-78,412
2.2 Number of at risk communities (wards) with a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan A total of 107 wards have DRM/Resilience Committees and plans in the new additional districts as follows: SIZIMELE:57 wards in Insiza, Lupane, Matobo districts ECRIMS: 50 wards in Mberengwa & Zvishavane districts
2.3 Number of communities with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively A total of 102 wards Mutoko: 15 wards Insiza: 16 wards Lupane: 22 wards Matobo: 19 wards Zvishavane: 7 wards Mberengwa: 23 wards
2.4 Number of women and men receiving trainings in the ZRBF programme (disaggregated by training type) A total of 78,412 have received training, of which 75% are women (58,809 females and 19,603 males).
Disaggregated results by type of training: Livestock production: 4,088 DRM: 28,955 Internal Saving and Lending Groups (ISALs): 8,248 Crop disease (Fall Arm Worm) control: 6,183 Gender: 1,047 Vocational skills and entrepreneurship: 1,301 Nutrition: 859 Climate-smart agriculture: 21,215 Value chains, markets and financial inclusion: 21,490 Crop production and agronomy: 12,588 WASH: 570 Non-Timber Forest Product: 1,529 ICT in resilience: 260
2.4 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF A Total of 11,772 households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (ECRAS 2,772 and ZVA 9,000) ECRAS: 1,297 male-headed, 1,475 female-headed HHs ZVA: 5,400 male-headed, 3,600 female-headed HHs
2.5 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type) 460 Disaggregated results by type of infrastructure: Boreholes: 119 Irrigation Schemes: 3 Dams/Weirs: 5 Crop and Livestock Innovation Centres: 6 Brooders: 9 CNCs: 4 Cattle feedlots: 9 Fishponds: 3 Improved livestock housing (Fowl runs, goat pens, 3 cross sectional kraals): 192 Solar-powered boreholes: 11 Low-cost water harvesting structures: 57 Watering troughs (livestock): 31 Animal Health Centre: 1 Dip tanks: 10
Output 3; Establish a crisis modifier mechanism that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas. 3.1 Crisis modifiers designed and built into ZRBFs multi-year development programs Aspects of the SOP and HFMS were updated and socialized to ZRBF partners in June 2018 3.2 Number of women & men assisted through the activation of ZRBF Crisis Modifier mechanism A total of 24,917 people (16,943 women and 7,974 men) reported to have been assisted by ECRAS.

ZRBF Year runs July to June Output 1:Building evidence to improve the policy environment and stimulate service provision to enhance household and community resilience 1.1 Number of risk assessments conducted, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men. Target: 3 1.2 Number of hazards mappings developed and/or updated at subnational levels Target: 9 1.3 Robust participatory monitoring, evaluation & Learning strategic framework is established, updated and operationalized Target: Successful implementation of MEL related annual/quarterly work plans deliverables that have been approved by SC 1.4 Number of policies, or strategies that were informed by ZRBF Evidence and Learning. Target: New indicator and therefore, will set targets starting from 2020. 1.5 Number of national and sub-national DRM or development plans developed, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis. Target: 2
Output 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change Target: 653,980 people
2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation Target: 54 wards 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months Target: 25% 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively Target: 150 wards 2.5 Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation) Target: 75% 2.6 Percentage of people who practiced the value chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project in the past 12 months Target: 25% 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF Target: 6,000 2.8 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type). Target: 400
Output 3: A crisis modifier that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas in place for the Fund 3.1 Crisis modifier designed, updated and operationalized into the ZRBF programme Target: Successful implementation of CMM related annual/quarterly work plans deliverables that have been approved by SC. The Activation and implementation of the crisis modifier adhered to SOP. 3.2 Proportion of ZRBF programme participants who are deemed food insecure at the peak lean season compared to the district population Target: 30% 3.3 Average utilization score perceived by ZRBF stakeholders who used HFMS to inform early action Target: New indicator to be measured starting 2020. 3.4 Number of districts with timely and complete reporting High Frequency Monitoring data Target: 15

Output 1:Building evidence to improve the policy environment and stimulate service provision to enhance household and community resilience 1.1 Number of risk assessments conducted, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men.- 5 national risk assessments were conducted with both financial and technical assistants from ZRBF namely; ZimVAC rural assessment, ZimVAC rural IPC analysis, First round Crop and Livestock assessment, Second Round Crop and Livestock Assessment and Poverty analysis report. 1.2 Number of hazards mappings developed and/or updated at subnational levels - A total of 10 multi-hazard mappings at subnational level were produced. These were updated from the 2015 national hazard mappings to inform the current resilience building programming. 1.3 Robust participatory monitoring, evaluation & Learning strategic framework is established, updated and operationalized -Met expectation: ZRBF Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning strategic framework harmonization and MEL reflections with all consortia partners have been conducted. This includes updating of ZRBF Theory of Change (TOC), Log frame and Performance Indicator Reference Guide. -Four (4) Quarterly MEL Community of practise meetings were conducted with consortia partners to trouble shoot arising MEL issues. -A total of 12 quarterly internal performance monitoring field missions were conducted as part of HACT to all the consortia partners. Furthermore, two planned joint steering committee missions were conducted for ZVA and ECRIMS project sites. -Quarterly consortia, development partners and steering committee performance review meetings have been successfully concluded. -Quarterly performance reporting produced and approved by the SC. -ZRBF PMU conducted the Outcome Monitoring Survey for the 7 consortia under ZRBF and results were used to report the top line outcome indicators. 1.4 Number of policies, or strategies that were informed by ZRBF Evidence and Learning. - New indicator to be measured starting 2020. 1.5 Number of national and sub-national DRM or development plans developed, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis.- A total of 3 district DRM plans were produced for Insiza, Lupane and Matobo, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis.
Output 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change - 750,056 people: 311,152 males and 438,904 females, were reached during the period under review through direct project support to 141,520 households 82,812 female headed and 58,708 male headed households. Disaggregated results by investment type: Livestock Production-82,558 Crop production -174,927 Community Financial Services- 82,124 Disaster Risk Management -155,592 Demonstration Centres-10934 Non-Timber Forest Products-22,980 Mechanisation- 720 Market Linkages & Value Chains-35,900 ICT & Communication-69594 Infrastructure-102,025 Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH)-20257 Trainings-80,992 2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation - 63 wards managed to develop DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation during the period under review. 76 wards plan and 3 districts plans were updated during the reporting period 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months - Overall, 33.65% (Males 31.6% and Females 35.7%) of ZRBF beneficiaries used financial services during the reporting period with 33.2% being youths aged 15-34 years and 34.2% being aged 35 plus. This indicator performed well given the macro and micro economic situation presenting in the country. With the multi-faceted approaches employed in the ZRBF initiative, The highest percentage was reported by ECRAS consortium (64 percent) with the lowest percentage with e ZVA consortium (21 percent) beneficiaries. However, comparing with the set target the consortia did well in achieving this indicator. Other consortia partners had 51% ECRIMS, 47% PROGRESS, 38% BRACT, 24% MELANA and 24% SIZIMELE. 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively - 184 wards 2.5 Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation) - Overall, 79.9% of ZRBF targeted households were practicing at least climate smart agricultural production technologies during the reporting period. Of which 79.2% were males and 79.7% females and 73.4% were youths aged 15-34 while 81.3% aged 35 plus. The highest percentage was found among the ECRAS consortium (97 percent) and the lowest percentage was found among the ZVA consortium (58 percent) beneficiaries. Other consortia partners had 92% ECRIMS, 89% PROGRESS, 77% BRACT, 76% MELANA and 83% SIZIMELE. 2.6 Percentage of people who practiced the value chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project in the past 12 months - Substantially exceeded expectation A total of 58.5% were found to be practising at least one value chains activity (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project during the reporting period. Disaggregation by gender shows that 59.1% were males and 58.1% were females. The youths (15-34 years old) were 58.4% while 67.7% were aged 35 plus. Further analysis revealed that 26.5% were practising three and more value chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project. Disaggregation by consortia; BRACT, 46.0%; ECRAS, 91%; ECRIMS, 76; MELANA, 57.4%; PROGRESS 62.1%; SIZIMELE, 62.1% and ZVA, 35.8% 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF - 6465 households were supported through the main project. SIZIMELE- 788, ECRAS-1940, PROGRESS 759, ZVA 1580, MELANA- 1398 and an additional of 3005 households were supported via Crisis Modifier. 2.8 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type). - 428 productive infrastructures were constructed under the main project (SIZIMELE 5, MELANA 4, BRACT 202, ECRIMS 71, ZVA 26, PROGRESS 21 and ECRAS 99) 151 Boreholes have been constructed under crisis modifier (ECRIMS 24, ECRAS 18, ZVA 22, BRACT 12 and PROGRESS 75)
Output 3: A crisis modifier that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas in place for the Fund 3.1 Crisis modifier designed, updated and operationalized into the ZRBF programme - The Crisis Modifier Mechanism Review –a formal review of ZRBF’s use of the crisis modifier mechanism has been conducted as planned. The overall objective of the Crisis Modifier Mechanism Review was to broaden ZRBF’s understanding of the adequacy of the CMM design, implementation context, gather perceptions about the efficiency, the scope and effectiveness of the Crisis Modifier interventions in safeguarding longer-term resilience gains, and document challenges faced in designing and implementing the Crisis Modifier activities. CM has been successfully activated and implemented in line with the SoP during the reporting period. 3.2 Proportion of ZRBF programme participants who are deemed food insecure at the peak lean season compared to the district population - New indicator to be measured starting 2020 3.3 Average utilization score perceived by ZRBF stakeholders who used HFMS to inform early action - New indicator to be measured starting 2020. 3.4 Number of districts with timely and complete reporting High Frequency Monitoring data - 15 districts under ZRBF programming produced complete and timely HFM data

The ZRBF Year runs from July to June OUTPUT 1: Building evidence to improve the policy environment and stimulate service provision to enhance household and community resilience 1.1 Number of risk assessments conducted, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men. TARGET 2. 1.2 Number of hazards mappings developed and/or updated at subnational levels. TARGET 0. 1.3 Robust participatory monitoring, evaluation & learning strategic framework is established, updated and operationalized. TARGET: Successful implementation of MEL related annual/quarterly work plans deliverables that have been approved by SC 1.4 Number of policies, or strategies that were informed by ZRBF Evidence and Learning. TARGET: 1. 1.5 Number of national and sub-national DRM or development plans developed, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis. TARGET 2. OUTPUT 2:Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change. TARGET: 730 000. 2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation. TARGET: 150 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months. TARGET: 30% 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively. TARGET: 200 2.5 Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation). TARGET: 80% 2.6 Percentage of people who practised the value-chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project in the past 12 months. TARGET: 40% 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF. TARGET: 3500 2.8 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type). TARGET: 90 OUTPUT 3: A crisis modifier that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas in place for the Fund 3.1 Crisis modifier designed, updated and operationalized into the ZRBF programme. TARGET: Successful implementation of CMM related annual/quarterly work plans deliverables that have been approved by SC 3.2 Proportion of ZRBF programme participants who are deemed food insecure at the peak lean season compared to the district population. TARGET: 25% 3.3 Average utilization score perceived by ZRBF stakeholders who used HFMS to inform early action. TARGET: 0.75 3.4 Number of districts with timely and complete reporting High Frequency Monitoring data. TARGET: 90%

The ZRBF Year runs from July to June OUTPUT 1: Building evidence to improve the policy environment and stimulate service provision to enhance household and community resilience 1.1 Number of risk assessments conducted, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men. - Moderately exceeds expectations Achieved: 3 national risk assessments were conducted with both financial and technical assistance from ZRBF, namely the ZimVAC rapid assessment, Crop and Livestock (first and second round). 1.2 Number of hazards mappings developed and/or updated at subnational levels. - Updating was done and reported in 2019. These are expected to be updated again in 2021. 1.3 Robust participatory monitoring, evaluation & learning strategic framework is established, updated and operationalized. Met expectation: - A revised ToC was endorsed by Steering Committee in 2020. - Portfolio review analysis was conducted for all seven consortia partners to examine progress towards achievement of ToC/Log frame expectations and to inform the anticipated cost extension. - Quarterly consortia, development partner and steering committee performance review meetings were conducted. -Quarterly performance reporting was produced. -ZRBF conducted the second Outcome Monitoring Survey. PMU report that the results were used to design the cost extension proposals. 1.4 Number of policies, or strategies that were informed by ZRBF Evidence and Learning. Met expectation: - At the national level, no policies or strategies were informed, however a Resilience Policy Conversation Series on Accelerating the Commercialization of Traditional (Small) Grains was conducted. - 2 (local/district level) policies were influenced by ZRBF evidence and learning under the ZVA consortium. These are Mbire Natural resources management and Livestock management and control bylaws. (Bylaws are considered to be equivalent to less than one national policy or strategy.) 1.5 Number of national and sub-national DRM or development plans developed, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis. Substantially exceeded expectation A total of fifteen districts updated their DRM plans in line with improved template that was facilitated by UNDP regional office support to DCP and consortia partners. These include Nyanga, Mbire, Zvishavane, Mberengwa, Binga, Kariba, Beitbridge, Nkayi, Bubi, Umguza, Umzingwani, Mudzi and Mutoko. OUTPUT 2:Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change. Substantially exceeded expectation 1,115,326 people, 426,719 males and 688,607 were reached during the period under review through direct project support to 210 439 households (80513 male-headed and 129,926 female-headed households) Types of support ranges from trainings, crop and livestock activities, productive infrastructure development, access to water and sanitation, internal savings and lending (ISAL) groups, safety nets, and disaster risk management (DRM) activities. Overall, the ZRBF programme has 20% youth representation. Disability information from four consortia indicate that there are 3112 Households with a person or persons living with disability and a total of 3928 persons living with disability. Consortia with disability data are SIZIMELE, ECRAS, BRACT and PROGRESS, with SIZIMELE having the highest number of households with a person or persons living with disability of 2913 Households. 2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation. Exceeds expectation: 301 wards updated their DRM or DRM/resilience plans, 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months. TARGET: 30% 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively. Met expectation: 244 wards with both an update to date DRM plan and timely submission of HFMS data. (PROGRESS-24, BRACT-29, ECRAS-29, SIZIMELE-57, ECRIMS-51, ZVA-54,). 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months Moderately exceeded expectation: Overall, 36.6% (Males 33.5% and Females 38.9%) of ZRBF beneficiaries used financial services during the reporting period. The results were 33.8% for youths aged 15-34 years and 37.4% for people aged 35 plus. 2.5 Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation). Moderately exceeded expectation: Overall, 87.8% of ZRBF targeted households were practicing at least three climate smart agricultural production technologies during the reporting period. The percentage of males was 88.8%, of females 86.9%, of youths (15-34) 88.3% and of those aged 35 plus 87.6%. 2.6 Percentage of people who practised the value-chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project in the past 12 months. Met expectation: A total of 38.2% were practising three or more value-chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the programme. For males, this result was 38.4%, for females 38%, for youths (15-34) 35.9% and for people aged 35-plus 38.8%. A total of 69.9% were found to be practising at least one value-chain activity (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the programme during the reporting period. 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF. Substantially Exceeded Expectation 5,080 households were provided with access to water and basic sanitation through the main programme activities against which this indicator is scored. 2,441of the households benefitted from latrines which came as a result of main project budget re-alignment under the SIZIMELE consortium, However, including the crisis modifier activities (which had additional funds) brings this figure to 14,443 disaggregated as 8,442 male-headed households and 6,001 female-headed households. 2.8 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type). Moderately exceeded expectation: 283 pieces of infrastructure from the main project activities. OUTPUT 3: A crisis modifier that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas in place for the Fund 3.1 Crisis modifier designed, updated and operationalized into the ZRBF programme. meet expectation: -CMM mechanism was activated twice, but with some delays. The CMM top-up was activated in February 2020, however faced some slight disruption of activities at community level during the COVID-19 lockdown period. 3.2 Proportion of ZRBF programme participants who are deemed food insecure at the peak lean season compared to the district population. Substantially exceeds expectation 14.7% food insecurity among ZRBF beneficiaries during the period of April to June 2020 disaggregated as BRACT 13.9%, ECRAS 6%, ECRIMS, 9%, MELANA 21.2%, PROGRESS 10.4%, SIZIMELE 17.6% and ZVA 26.4%. 3.3 Average utilization score perceived by ZRBF stakeholders who used HFMS to inform early action. Met expectation Achieved 0.76 3.4 Number of districts with timely and complete reporting High Frequency Monitoring data. Met expectation A total 93.5% was achieved thus 606 points on timeliness and completeness out of a possible 648 from 12 months of reporting for 18 Districts. Only two districts failed to make a submission for only two months (Insiza in February 2020 and Kariba in May 2020): this meets qualitative expectations of partners.
